intro: Chaetanthera limbata, commonly known as the white spiderflower, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the nightshade family (Solanaceae) and is characterized by its clusters of small, white, spider-like flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky, arid environments and has a sprawling, low-growing habit. Its leaves are narrow, opposite, and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are often branched and woody. The fruit is a dry capsule that contains several small, hard seeds.
